intro: Silene italica var. rhodantha, commonly known as the Italian catchfly, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its upright growth habit and showy pink or red flowers. The plant typically blooms in late spring to early summer, producing clusters of small, delicate flowers that attract pollinators. Its leaves are linear and slightly hairy, and it thrives in well-drained soils in sunny to partially shaded environments. Silene italica var. rhodantha is often found in grasslands, woodland edges, and disturbed soils across its native range.
